Author: Acura#2748
Content:
WARNING - Coinomi Wallet CRITICAL Vulnerability Made Me Lose My Life Savings
https://www.reddit.com/r/CryptoCurrency/comments/av7gfi/warning_coinomi_wallet_critical_vulnerability/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is coinomi wallet open source?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it was, but it is no longer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: tl:dr dont use closed source wallets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it does appear they send the passphrase to google for spell checking. of all the silly things to do with a passphrase, this is ranking near the top

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: does this warrant the use of @ everyone ?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: maybe. it could lead to total loss of funds, but i am not sure how many KMD folks use coinomi

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: can somebody pull the trigger then üòÑ

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: I did use it in the past a few times.

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: https://twitter.com/jyap/status/1100576879495401472

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: confirmed by Ledger but seems fixable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: everyone  it has been confirmed that the coinimi wallet is sending your entire passphrase, fully intact, to google for spellchecking. This means that google will have your passphrase in their logs, which they (correctly) wouldnt be treating as having any high value. It could just be they have not much security at all as to who can access these logs. How many people work at google? how many can get access to google servers with unprotected logfiles via some means? I do not know if these logfiles even exist or if they are indeed unprotected, but then again I dont know that they dont. The point is that it is entirely possible due to this design flaw of coinimi wallet. Strongly advise to move coins out of coinimi wallets before someone else does it to you

Author: Blackbeard#9921
Content: Here is a proof with video

Author: Blackbeard#9921
Content: https://twitter.com/lukechilds/status/1100613365850767360?s=21

Author: Philtr#9415
Content: Coinomi

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: luke childs has a screen capture of the entire passphrase being sent to google, not even scrambled (which would be bad enough). what were they thinking?

Author: Jay - Game#9014
Content: Crazy.

Author: Blackbeard#9921
Content: @jl777c the question is: were they aware of this ?

Content: and tested it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it doesnt just accidentally get coded into the wallet

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: Is it the coinomi app doing this in their code, or is it the client who is using a keyboard app with remote spelling check?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it degrades security to worse than central exchange security as I assume central exchanges protect their coins better than google would be protecting logfiles of spellchecker

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: @lukechilds it is the main coinimi app doing this spellchecking?

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: There are a lot of users with remote spellcheck enabled. And as coinomi is giving a plain text field, then users which such keyboards installed...

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: It would be better if coinomi will use a password field instead

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: regardless having system default behavior to be sending to google is a fatal flaw

Author: jiraymond#5665
Content: If I keep funds in Agama but keep a copy of my passphrase in Gmail you reckon I‚Äôm compromised?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: yes by definition

Author: jiraymond#5665
Content: Yeah

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: automatic spell checking seems impossible to turn off in many places and if that is using remote servers it needs to be fixed so no matter what the system settings, it is not automatically being sent

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: And I think (not sure) Google will protect it spell check better then most crypto central systems. Because for example the spell check is also used in Google Docs, which is having a high protection because companies use it for confidental information and so

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, trust in google then

Author: scubapanda#2485
Content: Here is some technical details: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5114708.0

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but there is no need to be exposed to this, so even if it turns out to be protected by google security, WHY?

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: @jl777c because it is a plain text field. It should be a password field

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: Apps should use password fields for this kind of data

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: And even then it can be send to Google if you have their password checkup Chrome extension installed https://www.theverge.com/2019/2/5/18211766/google-password-checkup-chrome-extension-data-breach-login-credentials

Author: dokrates#8987
Content: just change the ip resolving of googleapis.com and you will receive the text plain seed

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: @dokrates you can check if the domain is using dnssec and you can use dns over tls with the latest Android

Author: dokrates#8987
Content: warith also said: The team behind Coinomi are either extremely smart to add such backdoor so that when they get caught they would simply say it was an honest mistake or they are extremely stupid to overlook such security bug.

Author: Jurjen#9294
Content: http://googleapis.com is not protected by dnssec. So that is a bad thing for dns hijacking
